speaker: Skyline
text: The light atop the space needle glows._   [_Scene 1 - A newly constructed home. Frasier, Roz, and others are in work clothes.  The house is decorated for its presentation to the new owners.  The team leader addresses the volunteers._]

speaker: Leader
text: So, on behalf of myself, the volunteers, and especially the team from KACL [_Frasier and Roz give a quick enthusiastic cheer._], I'd like to welcome you, the Grant family, to your new Habitat For Humanity house.  [_The group starts to cheer.  Frasier interrupts._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, Ronnie, if I may...  [_We see the Grant family, husband, wife, and preteen daughter, for the first time.  Mr. Grant is about to accept the welcome, but is interrupted by Frasier's speech._]

speaker: Frasier
text: When my co-workers first signed me up for this project without my knowledge, I was, uh--well, I'll say it--irked.  But I'm glad they did.  Because I've had a chance to learn the pride that comes when you build something with your own two hands. As carpenter's helper, I sanded that newel post out there. [_We see the Grants becoming impatient at Frasier's speech._] As painter's helpers's assistant, I stirred the paint for the trim in the kitchen.  I was also surprised to learn that electricians [_looking at Roz_] don't have helpers.

speaker: Roz
text: It's getting dark...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, right, right, of course. [_to the Grants_] Enjoy your new home. [_handing keys to Mr. Grant_] I know I did, and if ever these walls should tumble...keep an eye out for my Harvard class ring.  Thank you.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: It's hard to believe the house is finally ours.  We can't thank everybody enough.  Thank you.  [_Everyone applauds.  The group disperses._]

speaker: Roz
text: Are you sure you took enough credit for the house?

speaker: Frasier
text: I took just enough, Roz.  It's not my fault I'm not licensed to use a plug-in tool.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, those guys... you don't need a... never mind.  [_Frasier is somewhat confused.  Fade out._]  [_Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment. Daphne rushes in.  Niles follows, carrying her equipment.  Martin sits at the dining table._]

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sorry I'm so late, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: No problem, everything okay?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_angrily_] My mum is a mean, spiteful woman!  [_Niles sets down the massage table, which Daphne then forcefully lifts and drops again, causing Niles to jump._]

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, maybe we should talk this out before you put your hands on me.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne and her mom had a big fight this morning.  Gertrude's been especially difficult to live with lately.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, last night, she got the neighbor's cat drunk again.

speaker: Niles
text: [_deadpan_] One of them threw up in the hot tub.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I told her, we will not tolerate this inconsiderate behavior anymore.  If she wants to be part of this household, she has to get off her lazy bum and help out around the house. How did I put it, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: I couldn't hear you.  I was in the panic room.  But you looked very forceful on the monitor.  [_During the previous exchange, Niles and Daphne have set up the portable massage table.  Niles now lines it with towels._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Anyhow, she pinched me keys and drove off in a snit.  Niles had to drive me over.  Why I'm so mad I could break something!  [_She abuses a towel, wringing it angrily.  She then beats the table with the towel._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Are you ready, Martin?

speaker: Martin
text: Let's give it a few more minutes.  [_Niles walks to the table and picks up a very small policeman's hat._]

speaker: Niles
text: What is this?  Has Frasier been attempting the laundry again?

speaker: Martin
text: No, that's Eddie's.  It's for a safety talk Eddie and I are giving at Glenbrook Elementary.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sounds like fun.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah!  We're replacing a talking parrot act.  Officer Chirpy and Sergeant Bob.  Dick Chirpy was one of the finest officers I ever served with.  It's funny, you know, with a name like Chirpy, you'd think he'd be the parrot, but as I said before, he wasn't, he was the guy.  The parrot being Bob.

speaker: Niles
text: That's fascinating.  Dad, are you sure you want to do this? I spoke at a career day once.  It was a disaster.  All the Taunting and yelling, I haven't been so... I haven't been so afraid of third graders since ninth grade.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, thanks for the warning, son, but Eddie and I will be fine. Hey!  Would you like to see part of the act?

speaker: Daphne
text: We'd love to.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, great.  Take a seat.  Come on, Eddie!  Show time! [_Eddie trots in._] Okay.  Eddie, what should you do before you cross a street?  [_Eddie looks to the right and left._]

speaker: Martin
text: That's right!  Look both ways.  How about if a stranger approaches you?  [_Eddie backs away, barks, and leaps on the couch, hiding behind Daphne._]

speaker: Martin
text: Right again!  Yell, and run to someone you trust.  [_Daphne and Niles warmly pet Eddie._]

speaker: Martin
text: Okay.  What about if you catch on fire?  [_Eddie jumps off the couch, pauses in front of Martin, drops to the ground, and rolls around._]

speaker: Martin
text: That's right!  Stop, drop, and roll!  What do you think?  [_Frasier enters from the rear._]

speaker: Daphne
text: I think the kids are going to love it.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see Dad's been showing you the act.  [_Eddie continues to writhe on the ground.  Frasier walks to a desk, opens a drawer, and removes something.  He attempts to close it, and it is stuck._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm.  Darn.  This drawer isn't closing properly.  I'd better go get my tools and have a look at it.

speaker: Niles
text: You sure you know what you're doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, please.  I built a house.  I think I can handle a simple drawer.  You know, it's probably the slidey thing. Or the drawer may have become warped.  If that's the case, then she's going to need to be planed, sanded, and refitted.  [_Niles kneels and examines the drawer._]

speaker: Niles
text: Or you could turn the stapler on its side.  [_He does this.  The drawer smoothly slides shut._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_dryly, somewhat embarrassed_] I paid good money for an upright stapler.  [_Frasier turns the stapler back up and attempts to close the drawer, which sticks again.  He walks back to the kitchen.  Niles rolls his eyes.  Fade out._]  **EVERYBODY'S GONNA FUNG SHUI TONIGHT**  [_Scene 3 - The newly built house.  Frasier has just knocked, and is being welcomed by the Grants.  He carries a mailbox decorated with a bow._]

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Dr. Crane, it's great to see you!  What are you doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I was in the neighborhood, and I thought I'd stop by to see how you two are coming along, and I also wanted to drop off this--this little gift for you.  I thought it would be perfect for the house.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Thank you very much, very generous.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: How lovely.  Thank you.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Come in.  Make yourself at home.  Sorry for all the boxes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, please don't apologize.  You know, this is a beautiful print. [_The framed print leans against the couch._]

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Oh, thank you.  Actually, we've been debating about where to hang this.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: I was thinking up on the wall.  [_He indicates a wall to Frasier's right.  Frasier is standing just inside the doorway._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh-huh.  Well, that's an excellent place, but uh, however, it comes to my mind that actually if you hung it opposite the front door, it would be the first thing your guests see when they arrive.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: What a wonderful idea.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.  Eh, um, actually, if you don't mind a little suggestion--um, if you put the couch, say...  [_Frasier pushes the couch to a different angle, causing the Grants to step back.  The couch now faces two chairs._]

speaker: Frasier
text: ...like this, you see, you've got a lovely conversation area, as well as a clear view of the television.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: You really have a gift for this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, gosh, it's hardly a gift.  It's a knack perhaps, a--a flair at best.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Wow.  Wait until we tell people that our living room was decorated by Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, please.  Hardly decorated, but you know, if you'd like to sit down and sketch out a few ideas together, I'd be delighted.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Seriously?

speaker: Frasier
text: Sure.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Wow.  Then I insist that you stay for dinner. [_She picks up a box._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, how can I refuse?  Here, let me take this for you. [_He relieves her of the box._] You know, I had a lot of time to think about this space when I was watching the plaster dry. I was plaster watcher.  [_They move back to the kitchen.  Mr. Grant has a decidedly impatient and uncomfortable look on his face.  Fade out._]  **BLOOD IS THICKER THAN LATTE**  [_Scene 4 - Cafe Nervosa Niles and Daphne are seated at a table.  They are waited on by none other than Gertrude Moon, who is wearing a green Cafe Nervosa apron._]

speaker: Gertrude
text: Can I help you?

speaker: Daphne
text: Mum, what are you doing here?

speaker: Gertrude
text: Just following orders.  Working myself ill, so I can contribute to Her Highness's household coffers.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sure Daphne only meant to suggest that perhaps you might help out a little bit more at home.

speaker: Gertrude
text: "Contribute" is the word she shouted down from her high horse. But I'll be glad to "help out" with the wages I earn serving strangers with my arthritic hands.  Now, how may I provide you with excellent service?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, uh, what would you recommend?

speaker: Gertrude
text: Not having children.  [_She leaves the table._]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_extremely irritated_] What does she think she's doing?

speaker: Niles
text: I guess this is just her childish attempt to embarrass us. Working here, she's hoping we'll retreat in humiliation.

speaker: Daphne
text: I stopped being humiliated after she showed up in that Spring Break video.  [_Martin enters in his uniform._]

speaker: Martin
text: Hello.

speaker: Niles
text: Hi, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_taking a seat_] Well, it's been 60 years, but once again, I am the toast of the second grade.

speaker: Niles
text: Congratulations.

speaker: Daphne
text: So it went well, then?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, the kids loved it!  When it was over, they all ran out and gave me and Eddie big hugs.

speaker: Niles
text: [_moving away from Martin, closer to Daphne_] Well, Dad, then you might just want to consider having that uniform cleaned.  Kids that age are always carrying germs.  God knows what you picked up.  [_He takes out a handkerchief and shields his mouth._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I'm sure any germs on their hands were jarred loose by their wild applause.  The principal asked us to come back and have an assembly for all the fourth graders.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, good luck!  It's well known that of the cruelest grades, ninth is third, seventh is second, and fourth is first!  [_Martin makes a puzzled face at Niles.  Gertrude again approaches._]

speaker: Gertrude
text: If you're not going to order, I'll have to ask you to leave this establishment.

speaker: Martin
text: Gert!  You working here?

speaker: Gertrude
text: At Daphne's insistence.  The blood is pooling in my feet, but at least I'm contributing to the palace's upkeep.  Say, maybe I could sell some of that blood, and give my daughter her cut. Is that a good idea, Daphne?  Should I sell my blood for you?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_deadpan_] No, Mum, you can keep your blood.

speaker: Gertrude
text: Did you hear that everyone?  My daughter's letting me keep my blood!  [_Martin immediately rises and exits.  The other patrons applaud Gertrude's loud speech.  Niles and Daphne rise to follow Martin as quickly as possible._]

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, that's nice.  Maybe we'll go have coffee at home.

speaker: Gertrude
text: No tips.  Nice.  [_Niles and Daphne exit with as much dignity as they can preserve. Fade out._]  [_Scene 5 - Exterior of the Grant home. Frasier knocks on the door._]

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: [_flatly_] Frasier.  Hi.  What a surprise. [_She is clearly neither surprised nor pleased to see him._] Honey, guess who's here again!

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Whoa!  Four times in one week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Chet.  How do you like the sconces, huh?

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Uh, good, good.  I thought you had plans tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I was just driving by and I noticed something rather alarming.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: [_impatiently, feigning politeness_] What is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: It seems somebody has put a--a cow mailbox at the end of your driveway.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: That's ours.  Chet put it up this morning.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: If you want, we'd be happy to give you back the one you gave us.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, that's not necessary.  It was a gift, and it was custom-painted to match the shutters--exactly the way I pictured it when this house was no more than a foundation. Now the cow is--is beautiful, but is it really the first impression you want to make?  Remember, a mailbox is a house's handshake.  [_The Grants are nearing the end of their patience._]

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: [_deadpan_] We like the cow.  It's cute.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Besides, we're thinking about replacing the shutters.  Maybe put up some awnings.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: And a screen door.  Wouldn't that be cozy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, I'm sorry.  Everything's going so fast.  I, uh--last night when I drove away from here, it seemed like we were all on the same page.  Now it feels like we're working at cross-purposes.  How do we feel about the accessories?

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: They're okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay?  Last night, they were to die for!

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: That doesn't sound like something I'd say.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I remember somebody saying it.  [_Mr. Grant is completely baffled and at a loss as to what to do to get rid of Frasier as politely as possible._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, all right, let's, let's just try to calm down here. Marge, why don't you go serve up some of that world-famous apple pie of yours.  We can all sit down and work this out.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: [_gently pushing him out the door_] Thanks, Dr. Crane, you've been a big help, but I think that we can take it from here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, but surely...

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Good night, Dr. Crane!  [_The door is closed shut with Frasier on the outside.  The Grants look at each other in relief and concern.  Frasier, clearly agitated, places his hand on the door, quite reluctant to leave.  Fade out._]  _END OF ACT I   ACT II_  [_Scene 6 - Backstage of an elementary school auditorium. Niles and Martin walk in, but Martin is struggling and clearly not well. He is in uniform._]

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, this is crazy.  If you're too sick to drive yourself here, you're too sick to give a safety talk.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting in a chair near a curtain_] I'll be fine.  I just have to get over this dizziness. [_He swabs his face with tissues._]

speaker: Principal
text: [_peeking around the curtain_] There you are, Mr. Crane.  I was getting nervous.

speaker: Niles
text: Listen, my dad's not feeling well.  I think it would be best if we canceled the assembly.

speaker: Principal
text: Are you kidding?  If we cancel this thing, we'll have a riot on our hands.  The teachers are expecting a free period.

speaker: Martin
text: The kids are looking forward to seeing the safety show.  Eddie and I aren't going to let them down.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, if you really think you can do this.

speaker: Martin
text: I can. [_He rises with great effort and exhales._] And by the way, you're just as beautiful today as you were the day I married you.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, I let that go the first time.  Sit down.  We're going to get him some ice water.  We're going to keep him off his feet.

speaker: Principal
text: Okay, but you'll have to go on in his place.

speaker: Niles
text: Heh-heh.  No, I can't do that.

speaker: Principal
text: Yes, you can.  Safety is everyone's concern.  And I can't guarantee yours if you don't.  [_The principal exits to the stage and stands at the lectern.  The hall is full of murmuring fourth graders._]

speaker: Principal
text: Quiet, quiet people, settle down.  Gameboys off.  Let's give a warm fourth-grade welcome to Officer Eddie and...friend.  [_Niles ambles to the lectern uncomfortably.  He is wearing Martin's hat. He leads Eddie, who is wearing his miniature hat.  Eddie sits next to the lectern._]

speaker: Niles
text: [_enunciating loudly and unnaturally_] Hello, safety fans.  I'm Citizen-Officer Niles, and this is my partner, Officer Eddie!  [_There is no reaction.  Niles becomes more uncomfortable._]

speaker: Niles
text: Okay.  [_reading from a card_] Officer Eddie will now show us how to act in various dangerous situations.  Say, Officer Eddie, can you show the kids what to do before they cross the street.  [_Eddie, who has risen, simply sits again.  The kids are bored._]

speaker: Niles
text: That's right, we wait for the signal.  Okay, uh, Eddie, show the boys and girls what to do if they're lost.  [_Eddie runs off the stage to Martin._]

speaker: Niles
text: Eddie?  Come here boy, hey!  [_giving up_] Children, I have a confession to make.  I'm not a Citizen-Officer.  I'm a psychiatric doctor specializing in marriage and family counseling.  [_The kids start to boo loudly, yelling catcalls, "Get out of here!" etc._]

speaker: Niles
text: I know, I know.  The point is... [_yelling to overcome the booing_] ...The point is that my father _is_ an actual officer, and he'd be here today, except he got a nasty cold, probably from some careless youngsters at his last assembly--which brings up a different, yet no less important kind of safety--hygiene!  [_Niles grins stupidly.  Martin reacts behind the curtain._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez.

speaker: Niles
text: I would like to introduce you to the first defense in the war against germs: Officer Pocket Square!  [_He pulls out his ever-present handkerchief.  The kids begin to laugh._]

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, okay.  Maybe it's not _cool_ to carry a handkerchief around anymore.

speaker: Kid
text: [_yelling from the audience_] It's not!

speaker: Niles
text: Is influenza cool?  Is scarlet fever cool?  Do you have any idea how many germs there are on just one finger?  Yes, that finger, for example! [_becoming passionate_] It's _millions!_ Or take simple dust.  Do you know what dust is?  It's the excretion of _mites!_  Little bugs that are eating your skin right now! [_He waves his finger at them._]  [_Niles has taken on a menacing, warning tone, as if telling a scary Halloween story.  The kids begin to warm to this._]

speaker: Principal
text: [_backstage, to Martin_] What the hell is he doing?

speaker: Martin
text: He's freaking me out, that's what he's doing.  [_Fade out._]  [_Scene 7 - Cafe Nervosa Roz enters and meets Frasier at a table._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz, hey, come and join me.  I'm in a bit of a pickle. I--I'm not sure the Grants are the right family for our house.

speaker: Roz
text: Who?

speaker: Frasier
text: The Grants--the people who moved into the house we built.

speaker: Roz
text: You went back there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Just a few times, yes, to try to share with them the principles of decor, room flow, general livability.  Then they literally showed me the door.  Yes, Roz, the very door I hung for them in the first place.  Take a moment to digest the irony.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, what do you expect, it's _their_ house.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I helped to build it.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay, untangling extension cords and stirring paint isn't exactly building a house.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I know I didn't do much.  The truth is I've never really been very handy.  In elementary school, I made an ashtray for my dad.  It caught fire.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, you did your part, but now you have to let go.  Poor family.  Probably think you're some rich arrogant guy who's bossing everyone around.  [_A waiter brings their coffee._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Lord.  Well, maybe I owe them an apology, Roz, I mean the last thing I want Marge and Chet to think of me is that I'm some sort of snob. [_with disgust_] Did I tell you they have a

speaker: Roz
text: My mom has a cow mailbox.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, sure, that's Wisconsin.  The buckle on the bumpkin belt.  [_Daphne enters._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Hey, you two.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi, Daph.  [_Daphne walks to the counter._]

speaker: Daphne
text: A latte, please.  [_Gertrude emerges from the back and approaches the counter._]

speaker: Gertrude
text: Daphne!  Here it is.  My first paycheck. [_She holds it up for Daphne to see._] $74.12 post tax.  See, everybody!  I'm helping out my well-to-do daughter with my pittance of a paycheck.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_playing along_] Thanks.  [_She takes the paycheck.  Gertrude doesn't seem to expect this._]

speaker: Gertrude
text: I suppose you're going to ask me to stop working here.  Well, I don't care if you are embarrassed.  I will contribute to the household like you told me, even if it kills me.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_giving the speech no heed and presenting the back of the check_] Sign here.

speaker: Gertrude
text: Right, then. [_She signs the check._] I'll just work here till I keel over dead.  Kindly set aside a few pennies from my pay for a nice casket.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_smiling_] Already taken care of.  [_Daphne exits with her coffee.  Gertrude is quite irritated that Daphne is not reacting as she expected.  Fade out._]  [_Scene 8 - School auditorium Niles continues his "presentation."_]

speaker: Niles
text: Four rodent hairs, and the head capsule of an adult grain beetle.  [_The kids enthusiastically yell out "Ew!" etc., followed by various calls of "Chocolate! Milk! Meat! Cookies!"_]

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, I heard chocolate, I'll take chocolate.  Per 100 grams, the government allows an average of approximately 60 insect fragments and the odd rodent hair.  [_Again, the kids enthusiastically react to being grossed out._]

speaker: Niles
text: But let's say you want to play it safe.  Maybe drink a can of fruit juice.  That's healthy... or is it?  Well, sure... if your idea of healthy is approximately five fly eggs and a maggot!  This is your government, people!  [_Martin and the Principal are watching in horror.  The kids react to Niles's last speech.  The principal comes forward to bring things to a merciful close._]

speaker: Principal
text: All right, let's thank Dr. Crane for coming by today...  [_The kids react with a chorus of "No's," as they have been enjoying Niles immensely._]

speaker: Principal
text: ...but I'm afraid we're out of time.  [_The kids continue to shout "No!" and "Stay!"_]

speaker: Principal
text: Okay, okay, one more, and then we have to say goodbye.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I can't leave without mentioning our friend, the hot dog.  Or perhaps it should be called "hot parasitic cysts, insect fragments, general grit, and rodent droppings." Thank you.  [_The crowd of fourth-graders stands in unison and applauds Niles enthusiastically._]

speaker: Principal
text: Thank you, Dr. Crane, for that most enlightening talk, [_glaring at Niles_] and right before lunch.  Everyone exit in a single line to the cafeteria, please.  [_The crowd disperses.  Martin approaches Niles, who gives him back his hat._]

speaker: Martin
text: Good job, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks.

speaker: Martin
text: It was touch and go there for a while, but you came through with flying colors.  Hey, quick thinking making up that stuff about the hot dogs.

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks, Dad, but, you know, I didn't make anything up.

speaker: Martin
text: I said it was _okay_ to make up that stuff about the hot dogs, which I love and had for breakfast.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well, I guess I was faster on my feet than I knew.  [_An African-American kid (James) approaches Niles._]

speaker: James
text: Excuse me, sir.  I just wanted to say, you were great up there.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  [_Niles and Martin begin to leave.  Niles than turns back to the kid._]

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, kid! [_He pulls out his packet of handkerchiefs, removes one, and tosses it to the kid._] Here.

speaker: James
text: Wow!  Thanks, Citizen-Officer Niles!  [_Martin and Niles exit.  Martin puts his arm around Niles, partly for support and partly out of pride.  The kid follows.  Fade out._]  [_N.B.: This appears to be a reference to the 1970's Coke commercial where "Mean" Joe Green of the Steelers threw his jersey to an admiring young fan after a particularly inspiring game._]  [_Scene 9 - Exterior of the Grant house Frasier and Roz approach the door._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks for coming along with me, Roz.  I'm not sure they'd open the door if it was just me.  [_Frasier knocks.  The daughter (Sandy) opens the door, which is stopped by a chain._]

speaker: Sandy
text: It's him again!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_talking through the crack allowed by the chain_] I--I'm sorry to disturb you.  You remember Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: [_making herself visible_] Hi!  [_Mrs. Grant has come to the door.  She is not pleased._]

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: I--I just wanted to say how sorry I am for my behavior this last week.  I've been intrusive and controlling.  I lost sight of the fact that this is your home--to do with as you will, and I sincerely wish you all many years of happiness in it.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: [_who has approached_] Thank you.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: You care to come in? [_She closes the door and unlatches the chain._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, we'd be honored to be guests in your home.  [_Frasier and Roz enter.  The entire decor is now a "cow" motif.  The couches have white covers with black Holstein spots.  The curtains have the same pattern.  It pervades everything.  There are even prints of Holsteins on the wall._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, look what you've done with the place!  [_Frasier controls himself admirably and forces a smile._]

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: Do you like it?

speaker: Roz
text: I think it's great.  What do you think, Frasier?  [_Frasier maintains his large smile and nods in mock approval._]

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Would you like to take a tour?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_with great restraint and forced enthusiasm_] Mm-hmm!  [_The Grants lead Frasier and Roz deeper in the house._]

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: We just finished repainting the den yesterday.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, Frasier, you've got to see this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh?  Oh... wow, that's purple! [_He smiles broadly and chuckles._]  [_Scene 10 - Time fade Frasier and Roz are ready to leave the house._]

speaker: Roz
text: Thank you again for the tour.  Your home is lovely.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: We like it.

speaker: Mrs. Grant
text: It's the kind of home we've always dreamed of.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_barely maintaining his pasted-on grin_] Yes!  [_Frasier turns quickly and exits.  Roz follows._]

speaker: Roz
text: Good night.

speaker: Mr. Grant
text: Good night.  [_Mr. Grant closes the door.  Cut to Frasier and Roz on the porch._]

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I am very proud of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sighing with relief_] I did it.  I didn't criticize.  I said nothing judgmental.  I didn't say a single word about their horrible, horrible taste.

speaker: Roz
text: You were great.

speaker: Frasier
text: I finally did it!  This was the ultimate test and I passed! I can finally let go.  Good-bye, house.  I release you.  [_He turns to walk away, following Roz.  Suddenly, he runs back to the porch.  He begins to move a chair from the right side of the door._]

speaker: Roz
text: [_offstage_] They're going to call the police!
